intro.para: In this chapter we will learn how to examine and use objects called ‘infinite sequence of real numbers’.

Sequences Informally speaking, an infinite sequence of real numbers is a never ending list of real numbers. For example

Each of these lists of numbers forms a sequence. Each sequence has a first number, a second number, a third number, and so on. Rearranging the numbers in a given sequence will generally produce a new and different sequence.

Sometimes the numbers in a sequence follow an easily recognizable pattern; as is the case for
sequences 1,2,3,4

The pattern in sequences 1,2,3,4 is:

21, 24, 27
Sequence 3: the next three sequence elements are:
????
1/32, 1/64, 1/128
Sequence 4: the next three sequence elements are:
????
-1, 1, -1
. Such a pattern can involve one or several previous elements, as is the case for
sequences 5
Example: Pattern in Sequence 5
The pattern underlying sequence 5 is:
1st sequence element: 10
2nd sequence element: 12 = 10 + 2 = previous sequence element + 2
3rd sequence element: 15 = 12 + 3 = previous sequence element + 3
4th sequence element: 19 = 15 + 4 = previous sequence element + 4
5th sequence element: 24 = 19 + 5 = previous sequence element + 5
6th sequence element: 30 = 24 + 6 = previous sequence element + 6
and
6, called a Fibonacci sequence
Example: Pattern in Sequence 6
The pattern underlying sequence 6 is:
1st sequence element: 0
2nd sequence element: 1
3rd sequence element: 1 = 0 + 1 = (second last sequence element) + (previous sequence element)
4th sequence element: 2 = 1 + 1 = (second last sequence element) + (previous sequence element)
5th sequence element: 3 = 1 + 2 = (second last sequence element) + (previous sequence element)
6th sequence element: 5 = 2 + 3 = (second last sequence element) + (previous sequence element)
7th sequence element: 8 = 3 + 5 = (second last sequence element) + (previous sequence element)
8th sequence element: 13 = 5 + 8 = (second last sequence element) + (previous sequence element)
.
Fibonacci sequence
Fibonacci sequence
A sequence (x_n) is called a Fibonacci sequence if, for all n\geq 2
x_{n+1} = x_{n-1} + x_n
This instance of ‘Fibonacci sequence’ appears as an example in the introduction to the concept of sequences.

We point out that the elements in a sequence need not follow any pattern at all. In fact the numbers in a sequence can be totally random. An example of a random sequence of numbers between 1 and 6 results from rolling a die: First number in sequence = number shown on first roll; second number in sequence = number shown on second roll, etc.

li.para: An infinite sequence can be used to approximate a real number as accurately as we want, and this is one of the main applications of infinite sequences and leads to the study of such a sequence for convergence.
It is possible that a ‘sum’ of infinitely many positive numbers gives a real number in a meaningful way. This observation is the starting point for the study of infinite series.

intro.para: Series An infinite series of real numbers results from ‘adding’ the numbers in an infinite sequence of real numbers. This is sometimes possible in a meaningful way, as in the two examples above. In this case we say the series converges. There are, however, sequences whose elements can not be added up in any meaningful way. In this case we say the resulting series diverges.

More information on Archimedes of Syracuse
and was motivated by geometric concerns: Archimedes approximated the circumference of a circle by starting from the circumference of the largest equilateral that fits inside the circle. A better approximation is the circumference of the largest square that fits inside the circle. An even better approximation is given by the circumference of the largest regular 5-gon which fits inside the circle, etc.
